Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Dawn Elizabeth Barnes of Emory University to conduct a research project, entitled "how protein structure plays a role in the contraction and relaxation of heart muscle," during the summer of 2012 at Nagoya University in Nagoya, Japan. The host scientist is Yuichiro Maeda.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project lies in the new knowledge being generated about the mechanism of regulation of heart muscle contraction at the level of single molecules. Using a model system, the nematode C. elegans, allows the use of genetic techniques for studying function of myofilaments in the absence and presence of key proteins. Also being used is cryo-electron microscopy to compare the calcium sensitivity of thin-filament proteins in wild type and mutant forms.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of our research was to gain visual evidence of protein conformations during the process that regulates muscle contraction. This visual evidence would help us understand the mechanism that regulates muscle contraction. We were unable to achieve this goal during the summer award duration because we had trouble gaining adequate protein expression for one of the three proteins (TnI). We utilized the fellowship period to screen different expression conditions. We were unable to acquire the protein during the fellowship period; however, since that time, we have screened other potential conditions and we were successful in acquiring protein expression. We have also conducted a crude purification of this protein and it functions are predicted.

     We were able to successfully express and purify the second of the three proteins (TnC). We were also able to modify the third protein (TnT) with a tag that would not disrupt protein function but would aid with the purification of the protein by itself, as well as the complex of three proteins, when they are joined into a single unit.

     In Arizona, I had the opportunity to mentor seventh and eighth grade students, in an after-school science investigator club.  The students conducted small-scale experiments in the fall, as well as a study for the science fair, in the spring.  I would like to work with Emory University to establish a similar outreach program. With my NSF-EAPSI experience, I will be able to share both the science and the cultural lessons with the students from challenging economic backgrounds. 

     I have presented the results of our work to our Emory University colleagues. I have shared my international research experience in the Fall 2012, Biochemistry, Cell and Developmental Biology program newsletter, on which I serve as an editor. I will also present the results of our work at the American Society for Cell Biology.
